docs.text: Installation and use of ROS2 Jazzy Jalisco on a Windows computer table of contents Installation of Ubuntu on Windows via WSL Installation of ROS2 Jazzy Jalisco on Ubuntu Installation of ur_robot_driver Robot and computer configuration Installation of Ubuntu on Windows via WSL Open PowerShell : wsl --install Restart the computer Open Ubuntu Create a default Unix user and a new password Installation of ROS2 Jazzy Jalisco on Ubuntu Setting language parameters locale # Make sure lines contain “en_US.UTF-8” else: sudo apt update && sudo apt install locales sudo locale-gen en_US en_US.UTF-8 sudo update-locale LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LANG=en_US.UTF-8 export LANG=en_US.UTF-8 Installation of packages sudo apt upgrade -y sudo apt install -y curl gnupg2 lsb-release Add ROS2 GPG key and repository sudo curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ros/rosdistro/master/ros.key | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/ros-archive-keyring.gpg echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/ros-archive-keyring.gpg] http://packages.ros.org/ros2/ubuntu $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ros2.list > /dev/null Final installation of ROS2 Jazzy Jalisco sudo apt update # Updating the list of available packages sudo apt install ros-jazzy-desktop source /opt/ros/jazzy/setup.bash # Environment set up Installation of ur_robot_driver Installation of colcon, it’s extensions and vcs sudo apt install python3-colcon-common-extensions python3-vcstool Creation of a worspace export COLCON_WS=~/workspace/ros_ur_driver mkdir -p $COLCON_WS/src Clone the ROS 2 driver repository cd $COLCON_WS git clone -b jazzy https://github.com/UniversalRobots/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver.git src/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver Installation of dependencies vcs import src --skip-existing --input src/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver-not-released.${ROS_DISTRO}.repos rosdep update #Updating the rosdep database rosdep install --ignore-src --from-paths src -y Packages compilation colcon build --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release Source the workspace source install/setup.bash echo "source $COLCON_WS/install/setup.bash" >> ~/.bashrc #Automatically source the setup.bash script for each terminal opened In case of compilation errors cd $COLCON_WS vcs import src --skip-existing --input src/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver/Universal_Robots_ROS2_Driver.${ROS_DISTRO}.repos rosdep update rosdep install --ignore-src --from-paths src -y Robot and computer configuration Setting up the Universal Robot 5.11 on the same local network as the computer On the robot graphic interface: Go to the menu (the three bars at top right) → Settings → System → Network Check information about the network of the robot: - Static Address is selected - IP address = 192.168.1.101 - Subnet mask = 255.255.255.0 On a computer terminal , check if the computer IP address is in 192.168.1.x form with the command : hostname -I If not : Identify Ethernet interface <eth0> by connecting robot and computer via ethernet cable and with the command: ip link Assign an IP address <192.168.1.102> to the computer sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.102/24 dev <eth0> sudo ip link set dev <eth0> up On robot graphic interface : Go to Installation → URCaps → External Control Set Host IP with the IP of the computer <192.168.1.102> Save On a terminal , check the connexion with the robot : ping 192.168.1.101 #if you get an answer, the connection is right Then launch the driver: sudo apt update sudo apt install ros-jazzy-rviz2 #Installation of rviz2 ros2 launch ur_robot_driver ur_control.launch.py \ ur_type:=ur3e \ robot_ip:=192.168.1.101 \ launch_rviz:=true
